transcript:
Patient: I found the thought records helpful, but challenging. It was hard to catch my thoughts in the moment, and sometimes I didn't feel like writing anything down because I was too upset or in pain.

Therapist: That's a really common challenge, Jamie. It takes practice to get into the habit of noticing and recording thoughts, especially when you're feeling overwhelmed. Did you find that it got any easier as the week went on?

Patient: A little bit. I think I got better at recognizing when I was having negative thoughts, even if I didn't always write them down. And when I did do the thought records, I felt a bit better afterwards, like I had more perspective.

Therapist: That's great to hear. Even a little progress is still progress. And the more you practice, the easier it will get. Remember, the goal isn't to get rid of negative thoughts completely, but to be able to notice them and challenge them when they're not helpful.

Let's look at one of your thought records together. Can you share an example of a situation where you had a strong emotional reaction and were able to catch your thoughts?

Patient: Sure. Last week, I was trying to work on a writing project, but my pain was really bad. I started thinking, "I'll never be able to finish this. My pain will always hold me back."

Therapist: Okay, let's break that down. What emotions were you feeling in that moment?

Patient: I was feeling really frustrated and hopeless. I think I wrote down 80% for frustration and 90% for hopelessness.

Therapist: That sounds really intense and overwhelming. And those thoughts - "I'll never be able to finish this. My pain will always hold me back" - what evidence did you find for and against them?

Patient: Well, the evidence for the thoughts was that I was in a lot of pain and I couldn't concentrate on my writing. I've had to put projects on hold before because of my pain. But the evidence against the thoughts was that I have finished projects before, even with my pain. And I know that my pain does fluctuate, so it's not always at its worst.

Therapist: That's really good evidence against the thoughts. It shows that even though your pain is a real challenge, it doesn't always stop you from achieving your goals. What was the alternative thought you came up with?

Patient: I think I wrote, "My pain makes writing harder, but I've overcome it before and I can do it again. I might need to take breaks or adjust my expectations, but I don't have to give up."

Therapist: That's a much more balanced and hopeful thought. And how did your emotions feel after you came up with that alternative?

Patient: I think my frustration went down to 50% and my hopelessness went down to 60%. It still wasn't great, but it was better.

Therapist: That's a significant shift, Jamie. It shows that even when you're in a really difficult situation, you have the power to change your perspective and feel a bit better. And that alternative thought - "I might need to take breaks or adjust my expectations, but I don't have to give up" - that's something you can come back to the next time you're struggling with writing and pain.

Patient: Yeah, I think that's a good point. I need to remember that I have overcome this before and I can do it again.

Therapist: Exactly. And the more you practice challenging those negative thoughts, the more automatic it will become. It's like building a muscle.

I'm curious, did you notice any patterns or themes in the thoughts you recorded over the week?

Patient: I think a lot of my negative thoughts are related to my pain and my writing. I have a lot of thoughts like "I'm not good enough" or "I'll never succeed." It's hard not to believe them when I'm in pain and can't write.

Therapist: That makes a lot of sense. Those thoughts are really common for people who are dealing with chronic pain and trying to meet high standards for themselves. It's almost like your brain has gotten into the habit of thinking that way.

One thing that can be helpful is to start noticing the patterns and themes in your thoughts, like you've already started to do. When you see the same thoughts coming up again and again, it can be easier to recognize them as just thoughts, not necessarily the truth.

Another thing we can do is start to look at the deeper beliefs that might be fueling those thoughts. Remember how we talked about core beliefs a few sessions ago? Those are the really deep, fundamental beliefs we have about ourselves, others, and the world.

Patient: Yeah, I remember. I think one of my core beliefs is that I'm not good enough and I'll never be successful.

Therapist: That's a really painful belief to carry around. And it makes sense that it would fuel a lot of those negative thoughts about your writing and your pain. What do you think would be a more helpful belief to have?

Patient: I guess a more helpful belief would be that I am good enough, even with my pain and my challenges. And that success doesn't have to look a certain way. It can just be doing my best and being proud of what I accomplish, even if it's not perfect.

Therapist: That's a really powerful belief, Jamie. And it's something we can work on strengthening over time. One way to do that is to look for evidence that supports that belief and challenges the old one.

For example, every time you do a thought record and come up with an alternative thought, that's evidence that you are good enough and you can succeed. Every time you keep writing despite your pain, that's evidence. Every time you reach out for support and connect with someone, that's evidence.

Does that make sense?

Patient: Yeah, I think so. It's like I need to build up a case for the new belief and against the old one.

Therapist: Exactly. And the more evidence you collect, the stronger that new belief will become. It's not going to happen overnight, but with practice and persistence, you can start to shift the way you think about yourself and your life.

I want to acknowledge that this is hard work, Jamie. You're challenging beliefs that have been with you for a long time. But I believe in you and I know you have the strength to do this.

What do you think about continuing to collect evidence for your new belief as part of your homework this week? You could write it down in a journal or even just make a mental note when you notice something that supports the belief that you are good enough and can succeed.

Patient: That sounds like a good idea. I think it will be hard, but I'm willing to try.

Therapist: That's great. And remember, you don't have to do this perfectly. Any evidence you collect is a step in the right direction.

Before we move on, I want to check in about your conversation with your friend from the writing group. How did that go?
